header_summary:
Keyser Söze and fanquake introduced significant advancements in the Bitcoin development community, focusing on enhancing wallet interoperability and security through proposed Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) and marking a milestone with the release of Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc1. Söze's proposals aim to standardize and secure wallet data serialization and encryption, laying out a framework for future wallet interoperability across platforms, with drafts available for community feedback ([BIP draft 1](https://gist.github.com/KeysSoze/7109a7f0455897b1930f851bde6337e3), [BIP draft 2](https://gist.github.com/KeysSoze/866d009ccd082edf6802df240154b20d)). Meanwhile, fanquake's announcement details the availability of the latest Bitcoin Core release candidate, emphasizing the importance of community testing and feedback to ensure the update's stability and reliability ([Bitcoin Core v30.0rc1](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/test.rc1/), [GitHub source code](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v30.0rc1)).

In parallel, glozow highlighted the improvements and bug fixes in Bitcoin Core version 29.1, focusing on transaction efficiency, security enhancements, and broader system compatibility, urging users to upgrade to this latest version for an optimized experience ([Bitcoin Core v29.1 release](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-core-v29-1-released/1978)). This release underscores ongoing efforts to refine Bitcoin Core, incorporating community feedback and addressing emerging challenges.

Jonas Nick introduced a comprehensive cryptography workbook designed for an interactive Bitcoin cryptography workshop, aiming to deepen participants' understanding of cryptographic principles and their application within the Bitcoin framework. This resource, which has benefited from extensive testing and refinement, covers a broad spectrum of cryptographic topics and is intended as a foundational tool for both practitioners and researchers in the field ([Cryptography workbook](https://github.com/cryptography-camp/workbook/releases)).

recent_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Standard Encrypted Wallet Payload + Standard Encryption Envelope formats
recent_posts.summary:
- Two proposed BIPs aim to improve Bitcoin wallet interoperability and security.
- The first BIP focuses on a CBOR-based wallet data serialization format.
- The second BIP suggests a secure container for encrypted wallet data using Argon2id.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc1 release candidate is available for access and testing.
- Preliminary release notes and a testing guide are provided on the Bitcoin Core DevWiki page.
- Feedback on this candidate can lead to its official release as version v30.0.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v30.0 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core v30.0rc1 binaries are now downloadable, marking a major update.
- A testing guide and preliminary release notes are accessible for review and feedback.
- Feedback is encouraged on GitHub to finalize the transition to version 30.0 after testing.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.1 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 29.1 introduces bug fixes, performance enhancements, and updated translations.
- Key updates include mempool policy change and adjustments to fee rates to improve transaction efficiency.
- The release emphasizes improvements in wallet and P2P functionalities, and development infrastructure updates.

recent_posts.title: Provable Cryptography for Bitcoin: An Introduction (Workbook)
recent_posts.summary:
- The workbook, designed for a Bitcoin cryptography workshop, offers extensive content and practical applications.
- It covers advanced topics and aims to deepen understanding in cryptographic signatures and security proofs.
- Available for download, the material seeks feedback for continuous improvement and requires basic mathematical knowledge.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Add BIP-0093 (Codex32) as application to BIP-0085
active_posts.summary:
- Ben Westgate proposes integrating BIP-0093 with BIP-0085 to create deterministic wallet backups.
- Codex32 aims to enhance BIP-0032 backups through error correction, hand verification, and secret sharing.
- The proposal includes test vectors, a reference implementation, and a draft PR for Bitcoin Core adoption.

active_posts.title: BIP Booby Trapped Wallets - Covenant-Only Taproot Outputs
active_posts.summary:
- Matias Monteagudo proposes enhancing Bitcoin wallet security with covenant-only Taproot outputs.
- The proposal aims to protect high-value institutional Bitcoin holdings by mandating script-path spending.
- It introduces technical specifications, an activation plan, and addresses security without compromising privacy.

active_posts.title: IRC logs: BIP 348 Workshop
active_posts.summary:
- Michael Zaikin facilitated a Bitcoin workshop on ctv-csfs-activation IRC at Libera.
- The session focused on Bitcoin Improvement Proposal discussions and transaction creation.
- The next workshop on 18 September 2025 will explore the creation and analysis of pools.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's mempool policies have evolved with initiatives like full replace-by-fee and enhanced spam filters.
- Compact block relay significantly reduces block propagation time, enhancing network efficiency.
- Solutions like weak blocks and template sharing improve network robustness and transaction efficiency.

active_posts.title: SwiftSync -- Speeding up IBD with pre-generated hints (PoC)
active_posts.summary:
- The SwiftSync analysis details `assumevalid` use and its role in improving validation efficiency.
- It discusses safeguards against inflation and transaction order validation enhancements.
- The document compares SwiftSync with `assumeutxo`, inviting community feedback for improvement.

active_posts.title: Addressing community concerns and objections regarding my recent proposal to relax Bitcoin Core's standardness limits on OP_RETURN outputs
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal to relax `OP_RETURN` output limits in Bitcoin Core has sparked debate.
- Critics worry about misuse for large-scale storage, altering Bitcoin's purpose.
- The discussion emphasizes the need for technical merit in decision-making and community understanding.

today_in_history_posts.title: SLIP-0039: Shamir's Secret-Sharing for Mnemonic Codes
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The TREZOR team proposes splitting BIP-32 seeds using Shamir's secret sharing.
- Feedback is sought on the "Master secret derivation functions" in the new spec.
- A Design Rationale is included for clarifications, with technical details pending.

today_in_history_posts.title: Both-side funded channels
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Cezary discussed both-side funding channels with Christian Decker.
- The channels enable single, trustless payments with mutual fund contribution.
- Cezary sought clarity on plan specifics and implementation timeline.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant tools softfork
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The proposed softfork activates BIP-118, BIP-119, and BIP-345, enhancing Bitcoin's security and efficiency.
- BIP-345's rapid deployment for Bitcoin vaults shows significant potential and interest.
- The softfork includes 7,000 lines of code and seeks community feedback for further progress.
